column1: Felty syndrome is a disorder that involves rheumatoid arthritis, a swollen spleen, decreased white blood cell count, and repeated infections.
It is more common in people who have had rheumatoid arthritis (RA) for a long time.
People with this syndrome are at risk for infection because they have a low white blood cell count.

A physical exam will show: - Swollen spleen - Joints that show signs of rheumatoid arthritis - Possibly swollen liver and lymph nodes A complete blood count (CBC) may show a lower number of white blood cells called neutrophils.
In most cases, people who have this syndrome are not getting full treatment for rheumatoid arthritis.
Some people benefit from removal of the spleen (splenectomy).
Call your health care provider if you develop symptoms of this disorder.
